title: A Five-Coordinate Heme Dioxygen Adduct Isolated within a Metal–Organic Framework
abstract: The porphyrinic metal–organic framework (MOF) PCN-224 is metalated with Fe
to yield a 4-coordinate ferrous heme-containing compound. The heme center binds O
complex. For the first time, this elusive species is structurally characterized, revealing an Fe
center coordinated to superoxide via an end-on, η
linkage. Mössbauer spectroscopy supports the structural observations and indicates the presence of a low-spin electronic configuration for Fe
adsorption data enable quantification of the Fe–O
interaction, providing a binding enthalpy of −34(4) kJ/mol. This value is nearly half of that observed for comparable 6-coordinate, imidazole-bound heme-O
complexes, a difference that further illustrates the importance of axial ligands in biological heme-mediated O

transport and storage. These results demonstrate the ability of a MOF, by virtue of its rigid solid-state structure, to enable isolation and thorough characterization of a species that can only be observed transiently in molecular form.
text: Metalloproteins featuring iron porphyrin, or heme, prosthetic groups are ubiquitous in nearly all forms of life. The heme functionality is intimately involved in a variety of biological processes, including O
transport and storage, electron transport, catalysis, and sensing.
transport and storage, mediated by the proteins hemoglobin and myoglobin, respectively, are essential to mammalian life.

The critical roles of heme proteins have rendered them a topic of intense study, primarily in order to understand the structural and electronic features that govern their functionality. Toward this end, tremendous concerted efforts have focused on the development of synthetic heme molecular model complexes that can mimic the reversible O

The study of molecular heme dioxygen model complexes has been hampered by their instability as mononuclear complexes. In the absence of a protein superstructure, heme complexes typically undergo irreversible oxidation via bimolecular condensation reactions, ultimately forming oxo-bridged Fe

This obstacle prompted the development of multiple elaborate porphyrin scaffolds such as the sterically protected “picket-fence” porphyrins, which served to prevent bimolecular decomposition reactions and enabled isolation of the first examples of thoroughly characterized heme-O
These systems also enabled studies to understand the role of axial histidine donors, present in both hemoglobin and myoglobin, in O
Along these lines, a longstanding challenge has been the isolation and characterization of 5-coordinate, or “base-free”, heme-O
adducts. Indeed, comparison of the O

binding affinity of such a species with their 6-coordinate analogues would help to further elucidate the function of the axial ligand in biological heme centers. Nevertheless, despite the elegant design of other elaborate porphyrin scaffolds,
adducts has been limited to spectroscopic evidence at low temperature, primarily within frozen gas matrices, as these species invariably undergo bimolecular decomposition or O
As an alternative to the above methods for isolating 5-coordinate heme-O

adducts, we hypothesized that a heme-containing metal–organic framework (MOF) would provide an ideal platform for the isolation and study of these species, as the solid-state structure of the MOF should prevent bimolecular condensation reactions and obviate the need for solvent to enable gas-phase reactions. MOFs are particularly well-suited for this challenge over other solid-state materials, owing to their porous structure, high degree of synthetic tunability, and amenability to single-crystal diffraction studies. Moreover, while a number of research groups have found success in explorations of MOF reactivity, the vast majority of these reports have centered on catalytic activity rather than the isolation and study of reactive species.
Encouragingly, numerous porphyrinic MOFs have already been reported, including those with open porphyrin ligands that can be post-synthetically metalated.
Herein, we report the incorporation of a coordinatively unsaturated ferrous heme center into a MOF and its reaction with O
complex. This species is structurally characterized for the first time, and combined spectroscopic and O
adsorption experiments reveal key features of its electronic structure and O

To the best of our knowledge, compound

These fits revealed binding enthalpies of −29(2) and −10.0(2) kJ/mol, which we assign to O

We initially hypothesized that this difference may stem from a high-spin electronic configuration for Fe

The observation of low-spin configurations for both
adducts systems eliminates the possibility of a high-spin state in
as the source of highly dissimilar enthalpies of O
binding. Furthermore, the temperature independence of binding enthalpy at low temperature, as ascertained through the O
adsorption experiments, suggests that a thermally induced spin state transition is not operative in
. Thus, electron donation from an axial ligand appears to be the primary source of differences in O

binding. Despite this supposition, the enhanced electron density at Fe in 6-coordinate Im-ligated heme complexes apparently does not engender a significant change in π backbonding, as the CO stretching frequency in heme-CO adducts has been shown to be similar in both 5- and 6-coordinate adducts (1973 vs 1972 cm
Alternatively, since the binding of O
effects a redox reaction at both Fe and O

centers, we hypothesize that the difference in binding strengths may be correlated to the relative redox potentials of 4- and 5-coordinate ferrous heme centers. Indeed, inspection of reported redox potentials for the Fe

couple reveals a difference of ca. 0.250 V between 4-coordinate and Im-ligated 5-coordinate heme complexes and likely reflects and encompasses the different ligand field environments and spin states involved in both systems.
The potential difference, when substituted into the Nernst equation, corresponds to a difference in free energy of 24 kJ/mol (see experimental details in the
). This value, while a rudimentary approximation, nevertheless is very close to the observed estimated difference in O
and 6-coordinate Im-ligated analogues. Thus, this analysis suggests that a critical role of axial Im ligation in 6-coordinate heme-O
species may be to generate a heme center with a sufficiently reducing Fe
The foregoing results demonstrate the ability of a MOF to enable the isolation of a 5-coordinate heme-O

complex, a species that has previously eluded structural and thorough spectroscopic characterization in molecular form. A combination of structural and spectroscopic experiments reveals unequivocally that this species comprises a low-spin Fe
center coordinated to a superoxide ligand in an end-on, η

binding in this species is much weaker than that observed in 6-coordinate analogues. This observation further highlights the critical importance of the axial histidine ligand on heme sites in globin proteins, as the absence of this ligand would lead to ineffectual O
transport properties due to a drastically weakened O

binding enthalpy. Taken together, these results provide an illustration of how the solid-state structure of a MOF can provide a platform to isolate and study unstable species that cannot be isolated in molecules.

A review, with 342 refs.  The authors review here structure and activity of cytochrome P 450, secondary amine monooxygenase, heme oxygenase, prostaglandin H synthase, indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase, and tryptophan 2,3-dioxygenase.
Mechanism of Oxidation Reactions Catalyzed by Cytochrome P450 Enzymes
Meunier, Bernard; de Visser, Samueel P.; Shaik, Sason

A review.  The exact nature of the active species in cytochrome P 450 enzymes (the putative high-valent iron-oxo intermediate) is still a matter of intensive debates.  Site-directed mutagenesis studies in conjunction with structural studies allowed different hypotheses to be checked.  Theor. calcns. became available and enabled various hypotheses to be tested and new solns. to be offered.  All these studies have enriched the knowledge on mol. enzymol. and the coordination chem. of metal-peroxo and high-valent metal-oxo species.

A review.  Metalloporphyrins are employed in various capacities throughout the biosphere, and of these, heme (iron protoporphyrin IX) is one of the most abundant and widely used.  Heme is well-known for its roles in shuttling electrons between proteins as seen in mitochondrial respiration and in O2 storage as is the case with globins, but it also serves as a cofactor in multiple enzyme-mediated processes.  Although heme enzymes can catalyze both reductive and oxidative reactions, the present review focuses primarily on those that catalyze oxidn. reactions, and esp. those for which crystal structures are available.
Giardina, Bruno; Messana, Irene; Scatena, Roberto; Castagnola, Massimo
Critical Reviews in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology

A review, with 110 refs., on several parallel biol. functions of Hb besides its basic function of oxygen transport.  In light of the information present in the literature, the following possible physiol. roles of Hb are discussed: (1) Hb as a mol. heat transducer through its oxygenation-deoxygenation cycle, (2) Hb as a modulator of erythrocyte metab., (3) Hb oxidn. as an onset of erythrocyte senescence, (4) Hb and its implication in genetic resistance to malaria, (5) enzymic activities of Hb and interactions with drugs, and (6) Hb as a source of physiol. active catabolites.
The synthetic analogs of oxygen-binding heme proteins
Suslick, Kenneth S.; Reinert, Thomas J.
A review, with ∼80 refs., focusing on the chem. of Fe(II) porphyrins and their adducts, which are most relevant to the functional properties of Hb and myoglobin.

A review, with 416 refs., is given on synthetic heme-dioxygen complexes.  Topics include: Hb, myoglobin, synthetic hemes for reversible oxygenation, thermodn. measurement of O2 binding, structure of oxygenated complexes, phys. properties (electronic, Moessbauer, IR, resonance Raman, 1H and 17O NMR spectroscopies), and cytochromes P 450.
Synthetic Models for Hemoglobin and Myoglobin
A review with 107 refs. on synthetic models for reversible oxygenation and competitive carbon monoxide binding of Hb and myoglobin.
Functional Analogues of Cytochrome c Oxidase, Myoglobin, and Hemoglobin
Collman, James P.; Boulatov, Roman; Sunderland, Christopher J.; Fu, Lei

A review of functional synthetic analogs of the hemoproteins cytochrome oxidase, myoglobin and Hb.  Topics discussed include synthetic Fe-porphyrins as well as analogs for the heme/CuB site of cytochrome oxidase.
Crystal structure and moleculsr stereochemistry of μ-oxo-bis[α,β,γ,δ-tetraphenylporphinatoiron(III)]
Hoffman, A. B.; Collins, D. M.; Day, V. W.; Fleischer, E. B.; Srivastava, T. S.; Hoard, J. L.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Crystals of μ-oxo-bis[α,β,γ,δ-tetraphenylporphinatoiron(III)] observe the space group symmetry of C2ca; the unit cell has a 15.197(5), b 25.077(12), and c 18.074(6) Å, and contains 4 oligomeric mols., O(FeTPP)2; the resp. calcd. and exptl. ds. are 1.30 and 1.28.  Detn. and least-squares refinement of structure utilized some 3501 independent, counter-measured, intensity data (Mo Kα radiation) retained as obsd. from θ-2θ scans for (sin θ)/λ ‾<0.65 Å-1.  The binuclear N4FeOFeN4 coordination group of the oligomer approxs. D4d-‾82m symmetry with an Fe-O bond length of 1.763(1) Å, an averaged Fe-N distance of 2.087(3) Å, and an FeOFe angle of 174.5(1)°.  The square-pyramidal 5 coordination around each Fe atom is entirely typical for a high-spin ferric porphyrin, the strong antiferromagnetic interaction of the ferric ions through the Fe-O-Fe linkage notwithstanding.  Thus, the ferric ion is displaced 0.50 Å from the mean plane of the porphinato N atoms toward the axial oxo ligand.  As is usual in cryst. porphyrins, the porphine skeleton departs significantly from planarity.  Bond lengths in the skeleton agree well with those in other Fe porphyrins.
Mechanism of autoxidation of iron(II) porphyrins.  Detection of a peroxo-bridged iron(III) porphyrin dimer and the mechanism of its thermal decomposition to the oxo-bridged iron(III) porphyrin dimer
Chin, Der-Hang; La Mar, Gerd N.; Balch, Alan L.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Addn. of O2 to toluene solns. of FeIIP (P = a porphyrin dianion) at -80° leads to the formation of a new intermediate (I) detected by visible and 1H NMR spectroscopy.  I reacts quant. with FeIIP according to the equation I + 2FeIIP → 2PFeOFeP.  A peroxo-bridged, dimeric structure, PFeIII-O-O-FeIIIP, is proposed for I on the basis of its compn., its antiferromagnetism (as detd. by the temp. dependence of the 1H NMR contact shifts and the magnetic susceptibility, 2.1 μB at 181 K, 2.7 μB at 224 K), and the detection of a mixed ligand species involving 2 differently substituted porphyrins.  Upon warming I decomps. quant. by the reaction 2I → 2PFeOFeP + O2 with no other species detected during the reaction.  The O2 produced was detected by mass spectroscopy and by its reaction with Fe11P.  The kinetics of this reaction were detd. at -22 to -40°.  The reaction is 1st order in I with ΔH* = 14.5 ± 1 kcal/mol and ΔS* = -15 ± 1 entropy units.  Isotopic labeling of the O2 used to form I reveals that the isotopic compn. of the O2 released due to decompn. of I is identical with that used in its formation.  However, when 2 labeled species PFeO2FeP and P'FeO2FeP' are decompd., the porphyrin ligands do scramble: PFeOFeP, P'FeOFeP', and PFeOFeP' all are formed.  Based on these observations, a mechanism for the decompn. of I to PFeOFeP is proposed.
Reversible oxygen adduct formation in ferrous complexes derived from a picket fence porphyrin.  Model for oxymyoglobin
Collman, James P.; Gagne, Robert R.; Halbert, Thomas R.; Marchon, Jean C.; Reed, Christopher A.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The synthesis is reported for the picket fence, porphyrin, meso-tetra(α, α, α, α-o-pivalamidephenyl)porphyrin, (α, α, α, α-H2TpivPP), which has great steric bulk creating a nonprotic cavity on 1 side of the porphyrin.  The unsaturated Fe(II) complex, Fe(α, α, α, α-H2TpivPP) reacted with strong field donor ligands to give 6 coordinate diamagnetic complexes FeL2(α, α, α, α-TpivPP), (I), for L = 4-tertbutylimidazole, piperidine, 1-methylimidazole.  Benzene solns. of I reversibly reacted with O, in the presence of a slight excess of base, as followed by visible spectral changes at 25°.  The fully characterized crystalline, diamagnetic dioxygen (sic) complex, Fe(O2)(1-methylimidazole) (α, α, α, α-TpivPP) was isolated from an O treated benzene soln. of I.
Structure of an iron(II) dioxygen complex.  Model for oxygen carrying hemeproteins
Collman, James P.; Gagne, Robert R.; Reed, Christopher A.; Robinson, Ward T.; Rodley, Gordon A.
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

The preliminary structural characterization of a reversible ferrous dioxygen complex is reported.  Mono(N-methylimidazole)-(dioxygen)-meso-tetra(α,α,α,α-ο-pivalamidephenyl)porphinato-iron(II), [Fe(O2)-(N-Me imid) (α,α,α,α-TpivPP)], (I), isolated from toluene soln., crystallizes in the monoclinic system with unit cell dimensions a 18.690 (3), b 19.514 (3), c 18.638 (3) Z = 4 Å, and β 91.00 (1)°.  R = 0.15 for 841 reflections having F2>3σ (F2).  The complex I has 4 pivalamido groups on 1 side of the porphyrin forming a hydrophobic pocket of 5.4-Å depth which encloses coordinated dioxygen.  The dioxygen is coordinated end-on, with a bent Fe-O-O bond.  The Fe-O-O plane bisects an N-Fe-N right angle of the equatorial Fe-porphyrin plane and is 4 way statistically disordered.  In addn., there is crystallog. 2-fold axis through Fe-coordinated O, and N of the axially bound N-methyl imidazole.  Thus, there are 2 types of coordinated dioxygen with the Fe-O-O plane either parallel or perpendicular to the trans axial imidazole plane.  Corresponding values for the Fe-O-O bond angles are 135(4)° and 137(4)° and for the O-O bond lengths are 1.23 (0.08) and 1.26 (0.08) Å, with a dihedral angle of 90° between alternative orientations of the Fe-O-O plane.  The Fe-O distance is 1.75 (0.02) Å and Fe-N (imidazole) is 2.07 (0.02) Å, suggesting multiple bond character in the Fe-O moiety.  The similarity of the Moessbauer spectrum of the model complex, I, with oxyhemoglobin indicates that I may be a good model for O binding in the O transport hemeproteins.
Structure of a dioxygen adduct of (1-methylimidazole)-meso-tetrakis(α,α,α,α,-o-pivalamidophenyl)porphinatoiron(II).  An iron dioxygen model for the heme component of oxymyoglobin
Jameson, G. B.; Rodley, G. A.; Robinson, Ward T.; Gagne, Robert R.; Reed, Christopher, A.; Collman, James P.

The structure of a solvate of mono(1-methylimidazole)(dioxygen)[meso-tetrakis(α-o-pivalamidophenyl)porphinato]iron(II), [Fe(TpivPP)(1-Me-imid)(O2)].1/2(C6H6).1/2(N2C4H6), was detd. using 3-dimensional x-ray diffraction data collected by counter methods.  Crystal symmetry is consistent with the monoclinic space groups C2/c or Cc.  The unit cell parameters are a 18.690(3), b 19.154(3), c 18.638(3) Å, β 91.00(1)°, and Z = 4.  Least-squares refinement of the structure in space group C2/c led to a conventional R factor (on F) of 0.109 using 1784 reflections with I > σI.  The crystal structure consists of monomeric units of Fe(TpivPP)(1-Me-imid)(O2) with benzene or 1-methylimidazole mols. occupying 1 solvate site in the asym. unit.  Dioxygen is coordinated to the Fe atom in the end-on bent-bond mode.  The Fe-O sepn. is 1.75(2) Å.  As a consequence of the 2-fold symmetry imposed on the mol., the 1-methylimidazole group and the terminal O atom are disordered.  Addnl. disorder is found for the tert-Bu groups and for the terminal O atom which can also occupy either of 2 crystallog. independent sites and which thus exhibits overall 4-fold disorder.  The 2 crystallog. independent O-O sepns. are 1.15(4) and 1.17(4) Å and the resp. Fe-O-O bond angles are 133(2) and 129(2)°.  The O-O sepns. may be underestd. by as much as 0.15 Å.  The Fe-Nporph sepns. are 1.99(1) and 1.97(1) Å and the Fe atom is displaced 0.03 Å from the mean plane of the porphinato N atoms toward the dioxygen ligand.  The Fe-Nimid sepn. is 2.07(2) Å.  Precise structure anal. is prevented by limited data of poor quality and by the disorder and high thermal motion of many parts of the structure.
Synthesis, structure and spectroscopic properties of two models for the active site of the oxygenated state of cytochrome P450
Schappacher, Michel; Ricard, Louis; Fischer, Jean; Weiss, Raymond; Bill, Eckhard; Montiel-Montoya, Regino; Winkler, Heiner; Trautwein, Alfred X.

Two O2 adducts of thiolatoiron(II) porphyrins, [K(⊂222)][Fe(TPpivP)(SC6HF4)(O2)] (I) and [Na(⊂18c.6)][Fe(TPpivP)(SC6HF4)(O2)] (II) [where TPpivP is meso-tetra(α,α,α,α-o-pivalamidophenyl)porphyrin; 222 is 4,7,13,16,21,24-hexaoxa-1,10-diazabicyclo|8,8,8|hexacosane; SC6HF4 is 2,3,5,6-tetrafluorobenzenethiol; and 18c.6 is 1,4,7,10,13,16-hexaoxacyclooctadecane] were synthesized by reaction of O2 with 5-coordinate, high-spin, cryptated alkali metal thiolatoiron(II) picket fence porphyrinate.  They were characterized by visible and IR spectroscopy: λmax (and log ε) = 360 nm (4), 427 nm (4.69), 560 nm (3.69), 610 nm (3.40) for both compds.; ν(16O-16O) = 1139 cm-1 in chlorobenzene and fluorobenzene for I and II.  Single crystals of compn. I·[K(⊂222)](SC6HF4)(C6H5Cl)(H2O) (III) were obtained by diffusion of pentane/xylene mixts. into chlorobenzene solns. of I at -5°.  Single crystals of II were obtained by slow diffusion of pentane into benzene solns. of II.  Structures of III and II were studied at 20° (III) and -100° (II and III).  III had space group P21/c (monoclinic), a = 16.806(5) Å, b = 14.331(4) Å, c = 52.000(15) Å, β = 92.95(2)°, V = 12507 Å3, Z = 4, Dcal = 1.28 g/cm3 (at 20°).  The final R1 factor was 0.085 for 5238 reflections having I >3 σ(I).  II had space group P21/c (monoclinic), a = 13.107(3) Å, b = 27.055(4) Å, c = 25.029(4) Å, β = 96.84(2)°, V = 8812 Å3, Z = 4, Dcal = 1.18 g/cm3 (at -100°).  The final R1 factor was 0.088 for 6587 reflections having I > 3 σ(I).  The Fe atom is, in both compds., bonded to the 4 porphyrinato N atoms (Np), the S atom of the axial thiolate and 1 O atom of the axially end-on bonded O2 mol.  The av. Fe-Np distance found in III [1.994(4) Å] is not significantly different from that found in II [1.993(3) Å].  The Fe-S bond length is 2.367(3) Å in II and 2.365(2) Å in II.  The Fe-O1 distances with the O atom of O2 bonded to Fe are resp. 1.837(9) Å and 1.850(4) Å.  The end-on bonded O2 mol. is disordered in both complexes III and II.  This disorder is, however, slightly different from one structure to the other.  Whereas the terminal O atom of O2 occupies 2 positions in III [τ(O2A) = 78%, τ(O2B) = 22% at 20°], it occupies 3 sites in II [τ(O2A) = 51%, τ(O2B) = τ(O2C) = 24.5% at -100 °C] (where τ = occupancy).  The est. of the magnitude of the nonbonded interactions between O2 and its environment located in a sphere of 7-Å radius in III and II is consistent with a static disorder of O2 in III and a dynamic distribution in II.  Moessbauer measurements were performed with polycrystals of III and II in the temp. ranges 5-197 and 4.2-295 K, resp., and under an externally applied magnetic field (6.76 T) at 4.2 K (III and II) and at 173 K (II).  The temp. variation of the Lamb-Moessbauer factor indicates that the Fe atom in these oxycytochrome P 450 models is not very firmly bonded, and is more like that in pentacoordinated than in other hexacoordinated hemes.  From the specific temp. behavior of the quadrupole splitting, asymmetry parameter, and line width obtained for II, the structural disorder of the terminal O atom of O2 is identified as a dynamic distribution over 3 different sites.  Corresponding values obtained for II are consistent with a static disorder of O2.  Magnetic spectra reveal that the oxycytochrome P 450 models are purely diamagnetic.
"Hangman" Porphyrins for the Assembly of a Model Heme Water Channel
Yeh, Chen-Yu; Chang, Christopher J.; Nocera, Daniel G.

I (M = 2H; R = OH; Mes = mesityl) was prepd. and reacted with FeBr2 to give I (M = FeOH, R = OH) (II).  The crystal structure of II was detd. Useful properties such as large internal surface areas, ultralow densities, and the availability of uniformly structured cavities and portals of mol. dimensions characterize functional metal-org. frameworks. Once these two issues are satisfied, the removal of the guest mols. (solvent from synthesis) without damaging the structural integrity of the material is often an addnl. challenge.  We expect that the advances in the synthesis, sepn., and activation of metal-org. frameworks could lead to metal-org. frameworks with new structures and functions, better and faster sepn. and purifn. of these materials, and processing methods that avoid pore blockage and pore collapse.

The Cambridge Structural Database: a quarter of a million crystal structures and rising
Acta Crystallographica, Section B: Structural Science

The Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) now contains data for more than a quarter of a million small-mol. crystal structures.  The information content of the CSD, together with methods for data acquisition, processing and validation, are summarized, with particular emphasis on the chem. information added by CSD editors.  Nearly 80% of new structural data arrives electronically, mostly in CIF format, and the CCDC acts as the official crystal structure data depository for 51 major journals.  The CCDC now maintains both a CIF archive (more than 73000 CIFs dating from 1996), as well as the distributed binary CSD archive; the availability of data in both archives is discussed.  A statistical survey of the CSD is also presented and projections concerning future accession rates indicate that the CSD will contain at least 500000 crystal structures by the year 2010.
